etymologies: Middle English: alteration (by association with either) of Old English nawther, contraction of nāhwæther (from nā ‘no’ + hwæther ‘whether’)

notes.text: The use of neither with another negative, as in I don't like him neither or he's not much good at reading neither is recorded from the 16th century onwards, but is not thought to be good English. This is because it is an example of a double negative, which, though standard in some other languages such as Spanish and found in many dialects of English, is not acceptable in standard English. In the sentences above, either should be used instead. For more information, see double negative. When neither is followed by nor, it is important in good English style that the two halves of the structure mirror each other: she saw herself as neither wife nor mother rather than she neither saw herself as wife nor mother. For more details, see either

definitions: used before the first of two (or occasionally more) alternatives that are being specified (the others being introduced by “nor”) to indicate that they are each untrue or each do not happen

examples.text: I am neither a liberal nor a conservative
he neither answered them nor looked at them

shortDefinitions: used before first of two alternatives to indicate that they are each untrue

definitions: used to introduce a further negative statement

examples.text: he didn't remember, and neither did I

shortDefinitions: used to introduce further negative statement

notes.text: The use of neither with another negative, as in I don't like him neither or he's not much good at reading neither is recorded from the 16th century onwards, but is not thought to be good English. This is because it is an example of a double negative, which, though standard in some other languages such as Spanish and found in many dialects of English, is not acceptable in standard English. In the sentences above, either should be used instead. For more information, see double negative. When neither is followed by nor, it is important in good English style that the two halves of the structure mirror each other: she saw herself as neither wife nor mother rather than she neither saw herself as wife nor mother. For more details, see either

definitions: not the one nor the other; not either

examples.text: neither side of the brain is dominant over the other

shortDefinitions: not one nor other of two people or things

notes.text: The use of neither with another negative, as in I don't like him neither or he's not much good at reading neither is recorded from the 16th century onwards, but is not thought to be good English. For more details, see either

definitions: not the one nor the other of two people or things

examples.text: they recorded two new albums, neither of which sold well

shortDefinitions: not the one nor the other of two people or things
